profileText: A Representative from New York; born in Chittenango, Madison County, N.Y., July 11, 1803; attended the common schools; learned the blacksmith trade; moved to Rochester, N.Y., in 1824 and engaged in the manufacture of iron; member of the Board of Supervisors of Monroe County several terms; elected alderman in 1841; member of the common council in 1843, 1856, and 1871; county treasurer of Monroe County 1848-1851 and 1854; elected as an Independent Republican to the Fortieth Congress (March 4, 1867-March 3, 1869); in 1868 established the Rochester Daily Chronicle, which was merged with the Rochester Democrat and Chronicle in 1870; trustee of the Monroe County Savings Bank; died in Rochester, N.Y., January 27, 1883; interment in Mount Hope Cemetery.

creativeWork.freeFormCitationText: Selye, Lewis. Speeches of Hon. Lewis Selye, of New York, on the tariff and internal tax. [Washington: F. & J. Rives & G. A. Bailey, 1868].

researchRecord.name: 1847-1879, 4 items.
researchRecord.description: The papers contain two letters from Jacob A. Barker regarding a press ordered from Lewis Selye for the Erie County Clerk's Office, 1847. Another letter is from A.R. Ketcham inc which he describes vent cocks belonging to hydrants purchased by Lewis Selye from Battin, Duncan & Co., 1852. The last letter is from S.C. Adams and concerns the Buffalo Police Department, 1879.

researchRecord.name: In the Sidney Ayres Collection, 1779-1955, 1.2 cubic feet.
researchRecord.description: The papers contain correspondence of Lewis Selye of Rochester, on Penn Yan business matters, especially purchase of a fire engine, 1838-1843.

researchRecord.name: In the Selye Collection, 1835-1909, 0.4 cubic foot.
researchRecord.description: The collection contains checks, promissory notes, bills, receipts, and correspondence of Lewis Selye, relating primarily to financial affairs between Lewis Selye and J.W. Bissell, Mortimer F. Reynolds, Matthew Rigney, and Everard Peck. Also included is miscellaneous correspondence, and papers of DeVillo White Selye, including letters to his father Lewis Selye, and correspondence relating to land in Rochester.
